**Guangcheng Collection**

*Scripture Title:* *Guangcheng Collection*. Seventeen juan. Compiled by Du Guangting of the late Tang and Five Dynasties period. Based on the *Zhengtong Daoist Canon*, *Dongxuan Section*, *Memorials and Memorials Category*.

**Guangcheng Collection, Juan One**

*Composed by Du Guangting, Inner Offering Attendant of the Supreme Clarity Palace in the Upper Capital, Imperial-Commissioned Literary Virtue and Power, and Purple-Robe Bestowed Great Master*

**Memorial Substituting for Minister Tao Fu on the Restoration of the Jin River Mouth Transcendence Sanctuary and Request for Its Name Plaque**

Your subject humbly states: The Jin River Mouth Transcendence Sanctuary is the eighteenth of the Twenty-Four Transcendence Sites, its seasonal node aligned with Lesser Fullness and its stellar correspondence with the Net Star. Traces of Chen Anshi’s ascension to heaven in broad daylight remain, as do the chariot tracks of the Lady of Bao, who attained the Dao. Each spring and autumn, by imperial decree, prayers and offerings are conducted here. Yet since the recent wars, all has been ravaged. The ancient halls stand empty, the altars bare, with only their foundations left. The sacred images and visages of immortals lie hidden beneath brambles and weeds. Pilgrims no longer come to pay reverence, and officials and commoners alike have no refuge for devotion. Who could have foreseen that this blessed site would fall into such desolation?

Your subject has undertaken its restoration, wishing to contribute to the sacred longevity of Your Majesty. I humbly recall that Your Majesty, heir to the numinous origins of the Xuanyuan Emperor and the immortal lineage of Mount Gou, succeeds Heaven in ruling the realm, governing the people through the Dao. The myriad lands bask in the vastness of your compassion, and the Three Teachings are renewed by your grace. The fields of magic mushrooms and the gardens of immortals all benefit from your solemn devotion. Even ancient temples and Confucian halls have received your restorative care. How much more, then, should this sanctuary of the Everlasting Life Teachings be honored with reverent repair?

Thus, I have cleared the overgrowth, rebuilt the halls and chambers, spared the sacred images from exposure, and enabled the faithful to resume their rites of burning incense and offering prayers. The distant traces of transcendence are once more a place of sublime cultivation. Lamps and incense now have their proper place, and the rituals of purification and offering suffer no lack. I have also summoned the Daoist masters Yang Xuanjing, Dugu Zhiyuan, and He [given name omitted], who have taken up residence at the sanctuary.

Yet, as the desolation endured for so long, the gate plaque has been entirely lost. I dare to beseech the favor of your beneficent grace, that this realm of gods and immortals may be specially adorned.

May I humbly beseech Your Sacred Grace to graciously bestow, in accordance with the former name of this sanctuary, a plaque inscribed with the august title "Shengshou." Permit this humble servant to craft and hang it, that the silver characters on jade tablets may forever bask in the radiance of sun and moon, and the immortal mountains beside the Han River may eternally celebrate Your Sagely Longevity. This servant is overwhelmed with gratitude.

---

**Memorial of Thanks for the Restoration of the Golden Register Daoist Ritual at the New Hall**

Your servant humbly reports: By imperial decree, I, together with Right Street Ritual Master He Chonghui and twenty-one others, conducted a seven-day Golden Register Daoist ritual within the new hall, commencing on the fourteenth day of this month and concluding on the twentieth. Palace Attendant Yang Shaoye performed the scheduled rites of obeisance, and the memorial of merit and praise has now been duly submitted.

I reflect that Heaven has blessed Your Sagely Work, renewing the grandeur of the imperial palace. Its jade terraces and vermilion gates surpass the palaces of the Three Isles, while its azure portals and cinnabar doors transcend the phoenix towers of the Nine Heavens. It embodies the splendor of the imperial residence and the solemn majesty of the Son of Heaven’s abode. All nations gaze in reverence, and a thousand spirits stand guard in awe. Scarcely had the construction of this jeweled palace been completed when the altar of the Golden Register was first established. Every detail was meticulously renewed, and each act of devotion was marked by profound purity. The fragrance of dragon incense ascended, and it seemed as though ten thousand sages had descended; the glow of the toad moon shone low, and it appeared as though a thousand perfected beings had gathered. May Your Sagely Lifespan be extended, and may the imperial realm endure forever.

Your humble servant, bowing in reverence, offers words of praise to the chief ministers, his heart filled with devotion and prayer. Auspicious omens have duly converged, and boundless blessings have been bestowed. May the great treasure of the throne flourish for a thousand springs, uniting the eight directions under one rule. We, your servants, have been favored with appointment to the sacred teachings and have taken part in these rites of devotion. We have feasted on jade delicacies from the celestial kitchens and trodden the cloud-paved courtyards of the immortal realm. Our honor is already beyond measure, yet further imperial gifts have been bestowed. We humbly acknowledge the gracious bestowal of supplementary funds, silver vessels, and bolts of silk—favors as deep as the vast ocean and as weighty as Mount Song. How can one as insignificant as a crane or swallow repay such sagely rewards? This servant is overwhelmed with gratitude.

---

**Memorial of Thanks for Appointment as Vice Minister of the Ministry of Revenue, with Additional Rank and Title**

Your servant humbly reports: By imperial grace, I have been appointed Grand Master for Splendid Happiness, Vice Minister of the Ministry of Revenue, Supreme Pillar of State, Duke of Cai, and Master of Broad Achievement. The warmth of Your Sagely Benevolence shines forth like spring, and the imperial brush has bestowed its radiance. Overwhelmed by such honor, I can scarcely comprehend its magnitude; burdened by such favor, I know not how to respond. Your servant offers his deepest gratitude.

I have heard that when a sagely ruler sits upon the throne, he must appoint the capable to office. When the worthy and good serve in government, they must exert their utmost. Those who ascend the ranks must embody the Dao; those who govern must be adept at adapting to change. Above, they must possess the ability to assist their ruler; below, they must fulfill the duties of a minister. Having found their proper place, they must apply themselves to the needs of the times. If they fail to benefit the people, they will surely incur the reproach of seeking mere favor.

As for your servant—obscure and timid—I have been honored to serve under such a radiant reign. Yet, looking inward, I see only my mediocre talents and dare not presume upon such extraordinary favor. I reflect that Your Majesty, in inaugurating this era and assuming the throne, has embraced the mandate of Heaven. Your wisdom outshines the twin luminaries, and Your virtue harmonizes with the vastness of Heaven and Earth. You have swept away the mists of corruption and revived the world. Your achievements have united all things in common purpose, and Your transformative influence has brought the eight directions under Your sway. Dreams have bridged the chasms of mountains and valleys, and Your ministers have answered the call of destiny; the mists and waves of distant lands have turned in admiration, and Your aides have fulfilled the omens of loyalty. The great pillars of state, steadfast in their support, hold aloft the sun and prop up the heavens. Heroes of the age, they are as stars descended from the heavens and peaks risen from the earth. The Eastern Palace aids in governance, and the sun and moon shine with renewed brilliance; the Southern Palace stands firm in loyalty, and the pillars of the realm are strengthened.

Your servant, a lowly being from rivers and lakes, possesses but modest talents. As a scholar, I have failed to achieve the heights of the unicorn; as a Daoist, I have been content to sketch the tiger. Moreover, I have been absent from court for many years, serving Your Majesty from afar. Though I have received no favors from mountains and streams, I have often been moved by the encounters of wind and cloud. For over thirty years, I have dwelled in seclusion, nurtured by Your light. The favors bestowed upon me are as weighty as Mount Song and as deep as the vast seas. You have transformed withered roots into lush grass and raised broken bones into robust flesh. Yet, though I call this a wondrous achievement, it scarcely compares to Your sagely rewards.

Thus, I prostrate myself in earnest supplication, my gratitude accumulating before Your Imperial Benevolence. Day and night, my spirit is stirred, and my shadow startles me. I have not repaid even a hair’s worth of Your kindness, yet my heart overflows with awe and trepidation. Now, at the dawn of this new era and the beginning of Your reign, You have bestowed upon me the elegant title of "Master of Broad Achievement," akin to the illustrious ranks of the Northern Bureau. I am unworthy of the discourse on serving the state with one’s person. How can I, who have failed to offer counsel at Your knee or present ideas to ease Your heart, presume to occupy such an exalted position? To covet further honors beyond my rank would be the height of greed. How could I dare to tread upon such extraordinary favor, ascending the ranks of the pure and distinguished? You have bestowed upon me a title as resplendent as the azure heavens and gathered my flawed being into the gates of mystery.

Yet, even in the Han dynasty, Dongfang Shuo was celebrated, and in the Jin, Pei Kai of Zhichuan was honored. Never before has one been granted consecutive appointments to such esteemed offices or twice bestowed with such exceptional ranks. Weighing my worth, I am filled with trepidation, torn between advancing and retreating. Facing Your Imperial Majesty, I have no means to decline. I can only vow to steel myself with diligence and forever repay Your boundless grace. This servant is overwhelmed with gratitude.

---

**Memorial of Thanks for the Imperial Decree Exempting This Servant from Joining the Two Teachings in Processions for Court Celebrations**

Your servant humbly reports: By Your Sagely Grace, it has been decreed that whenever court celebrations or congratulatory audiences arise, I shall no longer stand in the same rank as the Daoist and Buddhist clergy but shall instead be summoned alone for private audience, apart from the general assembly. Such exceptional courtesy transcends customary norms. The praise originates from Your Sagely Heart, and the honor uniquely illuminates the realm of the Dao. The weight of this favor is more than I can bear.

Your servant is both honored and awestruck, bowing his head again and again.

I reflect that Your Majesty, in Your divine wisdom, has inherited the mandate of Heaven and wields the symbols of imperial authority. You encompass Heaven and Earth in Your embrace and suspend the sun and moon to illuminate all below. The brilliance of Your golden mirror leaves no darkness unexposed, and the harmony of Your jade candle nurtures all things in spring. Thus, dew descends from the roots of Heaven, and Your grace flows across the face of the earth. You have pacified the realm through martial prowess, subduing the rebellious and instilling awe in the wicked; You have cultivated civil virtue to tame the distant and transform the treacherous. Even the nomads of felt tents and the dwellers of ice caves have come to court, offering tribute and observing the winds of change.

The realm settled, music arises; achievements complete, rites proceed. You have raised the fallen norms of the Three Dynasties and revived the lost canons of a hundred kings. There is renewal and reform, without faction or bias.

When the lords of the land assemble to pay court, You govern with ease, Your robes hanging loose, attended by ministers as stalwart as the Three Heroes and Ten Worthies, surpassing even the sagely talents of Feixiong and Shenxiang. The splendor of culture and ritual outshines past and present alike.

Some, clad in cloud-patterned robes and feathered garments, gaze toward the vermilion steps and raise their voices in homage; others, barefoot in square-cut robes, stand in the vermilion court and offer solemn blessings. At such times, this humble minister, though but a traveler in the ranks, has been permitted to approach the cloud-like steps, ever astonished at his own insignificance—like a mere ravine or gorge—yet finding himself lifted above the mist and clouds.

Now, Your sagely favor has been lavished anew, transforming all former observances. Though my humble person has been privileged to don the cap and sash of office and to enjoy the emoluments of a pure and elevated rank—my talents first employed in the northern ministry’s illustrious service, then transferred to the southern bureau—You have, in this moment of audience, singled me out from among the ranks of black-robed and yellow-clad officials, granting me a private summons to display Your boundless grace.

In former times, the Wei honored Jian’s reverence for Liang’s purity, and the Han praised Manqian while Qin lauded Ziping; yet even then, no new forms of ritual were devised, and courtly decorum adhered to established norms. Now, however, You have bestowed a mandate bright as the nine heavens and established a grand design for ten thousand generations. In quiet reflection, I am overwhelmed by awe; in my frailty and insignificance, how can I bear the grace of Your rain and dew? I can only strive to offer my utmost sincerity in eternal repayment of Your vast beneficence.

This unworthy minister is utterly overwhelmed.

**Memorial of Thanks for the Privilege of Private Audience, Ordered to Be Entered into the National Histories**

Your servant humbly states: By Your sagely grace, I have been specially favored with a private audience, exempted from the general summons. Moreover, my memorial of thanks has been ordered to be entered into the Histories. From the depths of Your imperial regard, this extraordinary courtesy has been extended, and my gratitude shall be forever recorded in the annals of truth, bearing witness to Your boundless favor. Overwhelmed by such honor, I am at a loss.

I prostrate myself in gratitude, reflecting that Your Majesty, in Your great wisdom, governs the realm, proclaiming sagely achievements. You have expanded the embrace of Heaven and Earth with martial grace and spread the radiance of sun and moon to illuminate all. The worthy and good have come to assist You, and the court abounds with ministers of exceptional talent. The Hua and Yi alike submit to Your benevolence, and the treasuries overflow with tribute from distant lands. All peoples enjoy prosperity and longevity, and without exertion, the realm approaches the harmony of Huaxu.

Thus, the palaces of Penglai and the halls of Zhi are all aglow with splendor; the sacred groves and imperial gardens are adorned with solemn magnificence. The Four Spirits manifest their auspicious forms, and the Six Qi harmonize in timely accord, bearing witness to Your blessings. The profound and the learned flourish, and the black-robed and brown-clad rejoice together. Though I am but an ordinary man, I have been blessed to encounter this glorious era, my name recorded among the honored and my office twice elevated to exalted rank.

Yet You have further distinguished me with singular favor, granting me a private audience. Amid the ranks of black-robed and yellow-clad officials, I received the summons and ascended directly to the heavens; in the court of the mandarin ducks and egrets, I glanced at my shadow and wondered if wings had sprouted upon me.

Now, this honor has been inscribed in the national histories, proclaimed throughout the realm—a grace beyond all precedent, forever enshrined in imperishable records. My long-standing dullness and insignificance cannot withstand the depth of Your rain and dew; my meager worth, like the smallest blade of grass, can never repay the virtue of Heaven and Earth. I can only devote myself to diligent service in reverent response to Your sagely wisdom.

This unworthy minister is utterly overwhelmed.

**Memorial in Celebration of the Yellow Clouds**

Your Majesty,

I, your humble servant, have observed the memorial submitted by Minister of Rites Zhao Wen-gui, reporting that on the twenty-third day of this month, as Your Imperial Majesty graced the De Xian Tower to inspect the troops, the Crown Prince returned from reviewing the cavalry encampment south of the city and entered the gates. At the hour of *you*, two golden clouds appeared above the city walls, shaped like canopies of blossoms, lingering before transforming into a purple hue.

I humbly note that at the birth of Emperor Yao, golden clouds descended in shelter; during the reign of Emperor Shun, golden clouds congealed in the heavens. Moreover, when Emperor Xuan of Han visited the Ganquan Palace, purple clouds entered the hall; when Emperor Taizu of Song ascended the throne, purple clouds manifested at the Gate of Uprightness. The Yellow Emperor had auspicious clouds by which he ordered his officials. Now, as virtue stirs Heaven’s favor, propitious clouds appear in the skies. Both Hua and Yi gaze in reverence; seas and mountains join in celebration.

I, your servant, offer my deepest congratulations. Your Majesty embodies the Dao and wields the Mandate, divinely endowed with sagely wisdom. Your benevolence embraces all living things; your grace extends across the earth. You pacify distant lands with civil brilliance and subdue fierce foes with martial prowess. As the Central Plains remain unsettled and all things restless, you have resolved to restore order and relieve the suffering of the people. Your commands have crushed the southern rebels like serpents; your campaigns have swept away the northern dust like smoke. Iron axles and dragon-prowed ships gleam upon the waters; frost-edged spears and snow-bright halberds march upon the land. Mountains and rivers tremble at your might; thunder and lightning hasten at your call. With boundless magnanimity, you expand the realm of Heaven and Earth.

Thus, you have entrusted the Crown Prince with the training of the Six Armies and the enforcement of the Three Commands. Warriors in chariots and armored ranks soar with valor; men of titanic strength blaze with courage bright as the sun. All stand firm as metal and stone, their loyalty unshaken. Truly in accord with Heaven’s will, the divine favor has manifested: twin clouds arose in majestic splendor, their forms coalescing like golden branches and jade leaves. High above the imperial throne, they deepened to purple, resembling blossoms in full bloom, descending to embrace the royal city. First assuming the guise of a cauldron’s shade, they gradually took on the hue of a frontier pass—clear signs that the vault of Heaven applauds your virtue, now ascendant. This surpasses the omens of Yao and Shun, exceeds the portents of Han Xuan and Song Taizu. Henceforth, the eight wilds shall submit as guests, and the myriad lands shall share a single path. May your sagely years stretch into the thousands and millions; may your grand foundation stand eternal and unshaken.

I, your servant, have been deeply favored by your wisdom and twice witnessed these wondrous signs. Dare I compose verse to express my sincerity and offer song to extol your sagely virtue? I humbly present a poem in tribute.

**Memorial in Celebration of the White Magpie**

I have further observed that Li Yan-tao, a commoner of Chongshan Village in Duogong District of Yandao County, captured a white magpie from a nanmu tree and presented it as tribute. The Five Phases reveal their auspiciousness, heralding the flourishing of the Metal Cycle; all officials gaze in unison, celebrating the celestial bounty bestowed upon the Jade Capital.

I, your servant, offer my most sincere congratulations. I have heard that when a true king rectifies names and establishes teachings, he embodies Heaven’s will, curbs cruelty and eliminates slaughter, thus comforting the hearts of the people. Then do rare trees and precious birds appear, coming to pay court at the palace gates—frost-touched feathers stirring with color, deep-blue talons marking their marvel. Folding their wings to display their form, they put to shame the vain boasts of Han and Wei; transmitting their cries to convey joy, they soar in homage to Your August Brilliance.

I humbly reflect that Your Majesty’s auspicious signs surpass those of all former kings, your achievements transcend those of the Three Antiquities. In harmonious sequence, winds and rains follow the measures of Yu; dispelling darkness, your mirror-like wisdom fills the halls of Xuantai. Nurturing all within the Four Seas, you have twice established the foundation of Heaven and Earth; illuminating the lands below, you have renewed the radiance of sun and moon. You have outshone the feeble Han, whose people rested their shoulders, and surpassed the contented Tang, whose people drummed their bellies. The people sing of abundant harvests; all things rely on the peace of the times.

Moreover, your legions—tens of thousands of fierce warriors, thousands of encampments gleaming with armor—capture the wicked and eradicate corruption, shelter the weak and nurture the orphaned. Thunderous rolls of war drums advance; clouds darken with the unfurling of banners. At your commands, the bold and mighty leap to action; through your grace, the weary and afflicted revive. The Five Planets move in their courses to bestow blessings; the Eight Seas submit to your influence and calm their waves. Thus do mountains and rivers offer their felicity, and birds and beasts present their omens.

Far from their nests upon the sea, they come to face the palace amid the clouds. Behold them in their jade cages, their snowy forms revealed at a glance. Unstartled, they do not circle the imperial gardens in flight, but before your celestial benevolence, they dance with joy. Coming and going along the jade steps, perching beside the beaded curtains, their pure white plumage is hard to distinguish, yet their new songs sound familiar. They are no companions for bridge-building magpies, nor are they part of flocks circling trees. Having manifested their snowy-white beauty, they truly herald the flourishing of the Metal Cycle.

I await the day when weapons are laid down and treachery is eradicated. The smoke and beacons of the battlefield shall be swept away, forever returning to the North Star; the brambles and thorns of the realm shall be stilled, pacified from the West. Truly, you surpass the might of Wei’s virtue and eclipse the achievements of Han’s prosperity.

I, your servant, have been blessed to witness this flourishing era and repeatedly behold these wondrous signs. Thus, I dare to present verses of song and praise, humbly offering them for Your Sagely Inspection.

I further humbly submit a poem in celebration of your sagely virtue and the auspicious omen.

**Memorial in Celebration of the Auspicious Grain Presented by Tianzhen Army**

I, your servant, have observed that Cui Shan, Acting Military Commissioner of Tianzhen Army, has presented a depiction of double-eared grain offered by Wang Youtian, a commoner of Shehong County. Your sagely virtue reaches far, and auspicious signs arrive in succession. Civil and military officials gaze upon them in awe; all within and beyond the realm rejoice.

I, your servant, have consulted the Auspicious Omens Record, which states: "Auspicious grain is a most excellent omen. In years of abundance, when the ruler’s virtue extends to the earth, two stalks grow from a single root." In ancient times, Tang Shu obtained such grain, with different fields bearing identical ears. King Cheng asked the Duke of Zhou: "Does two ears on one stalk signify that all under Heaven is in harmony?" The king commanded Tang Shu to compose the *Ode to Auspicious Grain*. Thereafter, the Nine Lands were united, the Eight Directions submitted, tribute of mastiffs came from the west, and pheasants arrived from the south. For thirty generations, the grand foundation endured; for seven hundred years, the great enterprise flourished—outshining the Xia and eclipsing the Shang.

Now, in this sagely and enlightened age, such an omen has again appeared. I humbly reflect that Your Majesty has inherited the sacred lineage of the Xuanyuan Emperor and carries forward the great source of the Zhou sovereigns. Aligned with the Mandate of Heaven, you unite Hua and Yi as one, ruling like the Thearch. In reverence and frugality, you have renounced the pleasures of music and wine; in sagacity and divine insight, you possess the clarity of keen sight and sharp hearing. Spreading martial virtue, you first punish those who defy the law, sweeping away treacherous rebels like lightning; disseminating civil culture, you swiftly pacify the Rong and Qiang, who come bearing tribute like clouds. You labor with concern for the people’s welfare, pitying the toil of farmers. Year after year, harvests are bountiful; fields know neither drought nor flood.

Your virtue reaches the earth, manifesting in the shared bloom of two stalks; your resonance with Heaven is revealed in the identical ears from different fields. This fulfills the omen of the sagely ancestors and heralds the Zhou’s auspicious grain; it signifies our sovereign’s expansion of the realm. In the past, harmony united Heaven and Earth as one; now, your embrace encompasses all lands in a single realm. Moreover, as the royal armies prepare for punitive campaigns, swearing to relieve the people’s suffering, your awe-inspiring might has already cowed distant lands, and auspicious signs first appear in nearby regions. We await the restoration of peace, the eternal dispelling of miasmic turmoil. You shall reveal the radiance of sun and moon across the Nine Heavens, fulfilling the Zhou’s divinations; you shall unite the hopes of all living beings across the Four Seas, matching the Tang’s auspicious grain.

I, your servant, gazing upon the Auspicious Omens Record, join in singing of your sagely influence. I wish to be included in the annals of those who gather poems, aspiring to follow in the footsteps of Tang Shu’s ode. I humbly submit a poem in praise of your sagely virtue and the double-eared grain.

**Memorial Requesting That the Imperial Carriage Not Proceed to the Northern Army Front**

I, your servant, have received the imperial decree that the imperial carriage shall proceed to the northern army front.

Your servant has heard that the inspection of righteous deeds and the review of meritorious service are enduring rites handed down in the ritual classics, while the punitive expedition against rebels and the suppression of traitors are universal norms of statecraft. Such measures aim to extend radiant illumination to every region and to gather the five auspicious omens from the feudal lords. They serve to eradicate violence and disorder, bringing solace to the suffering masses. Yet the rebellious tribes of Bin and Qi, long deluded and estranged from the Great Norm, shall soon—indeed, within days—witness their annihilation. There is no need for Your Imperial Carriage to personally advance upon the war chariot, venturing afar to the lair of cunning foes. The earnest pleas of the multitude, united in their apprehension, give rise to widespread alarm and doubt.

I humbly reflect that Your Majesty surpasses the luminous virtue of Shun and transcends the divine martial prowess of the Zhou kings. You wield the commanding severity of autumn frost while bestowing the nurturing breath of spring’s renewal. Entrusting all to perfect impartiality and extending boundless sincerity, your transforming influence sweeps across the realm like wind bending grass. Yet in the lands of Long and Wei, among the customs of Qian and Qi, the people have grown accustomed to the harsh qi of frigid valleys, forsaking the warmth of yang; they have embraced the yin of foul waters, shunning the solitary radiance of your illumination. Relying on anthill-like fortifications for false security, they nest in tented encampments, clinging to fleeting peace.

Now, with your supreme generals leading the expedition and your mighty armies pressing the assault, your celestial strategies shall surely sever the roots of rebellion. I privately consider that the roads of Hanqu and Baochuan, now gripped by winter’s chill, present perilous paths where frost and snow render the treacherous passes nearly impassable. How easily could they be ascended? To loose a thousand-jun crossbow at a mere minnow or a fly would be as futile as expending the awe of ten thousand chariots upon a desolate, crumbling fortress. I humbly beseech Your Sagely Compassion to heed the will of the people, to revoke the decree, and to await the triumphant news of victory, thereby ensuring the eternal unity of Hua and Yi.

In presumptuous defiance of Your Celestial Majesty’s authority, I am seized by trembling, dread, and overwhelming trepidation. With utmost reverence, I present this memorial at the palace gate, prostrating myself in gratitude.

**Second Memorial**

Your servant has received the imperial decree that the imperial carriage shall proceed to the northern army front, and that the Crown Prince, the chief ministers, and all officials have submitted memorials in earnest petition, yet no assent has been granted.

Though the inspection of regional customs and mores is an ancient rite of the classics, the consolation and reassurance of the troops reflect the compassionate illumination of a sovereign and father.

Yet the journey is fraught with peril—land and water congeal in harsh rigor, while hearts near and far burn with genuine anxiety. I humbly reflect that Your Imperial Majesty embodies the compassion of Yao and surpasses the wisdom of Shun, desiring that all within the four seas bathe in the harmony of your transformative virtue. Yet in the regions of Qian and Long, so close to the frontier, long-standing covenants have been betrayed, and profound trust has been violated. Those who recognize the need for change have already bound themselves to loyalty; those still lost in defiance cling to false security, covering their ears. Thus, the people of this land nurse grievances accumulated over years. They have long witnessed the barking of dogs at Yao, yet yearn for Shun with no means to reach him. Therefore, you have entrusted generals with halberds to marshal the troops and erected altars to swear oaths before the masses. Commands fly like the wind, and valor surges like rain. The might of your commanders shakes the earth like thunder, their resolve firm as iron and stone. They pledge to achieve victory by a set date, ensuring the land’s pacification. Why then should Your Majesty personally ride the jade carriage, wielding white-feathered arrows? Six dragons and eight steeds would traverse treacherous paths; ten thousand riders and a thousand officials would traverse distant peaks beyond. Frost and snow now fall, and biting cold draws near. I humbly beseech Your Celestial Mercy to heed the sentiments of the myriad people and temporarily suspend the command to inspect the frontier. Thus, you will uphold the ancestral altars above and console the hearts of Hua and Yi below. Awaiting the triumphant report, may your realm expand further. Overwhelmed by Your Majesty’s profound favor, I yet feel unworthy of such luminous sincerity. My trespass against your august dignity is unbearable; my longing for grace is urgent, and my prayers are fervent.

**Memorial of Thanks for the Imperial Favor to Renovate Xingsheng Abbey under Master Hongyi Zhang Qian**

Your servant has received the imperial decree granting Master Hongyi Zhang Qian of Xingsheng Abbey on the Left Street the honor of renovating and presiding over the abbey. This grace flows from Your Majesty’s sacred heart, bestowing glory upon the realm of the Dao. The robes of the faithful rejoice, and the sacred groves shine with renewed splendor. I prostrate myself in gratitude, reflecting that Your Majesty’s Dao equals that of the Yellow Emperor and your sagacity rivals that of Emperor Yao. You dwell in thought upon the peaks of Guye and dream of the land of Huaxu. In your care for the great teachings, principle harmonizes with the wellspring of life. The spiritual and the formless merge in non-action, while your mind cherishes those of hidden virtue. Your transformative influence aligns with purity and stillness, benefiting the state and its people. Yet the abbey’s halls stood desolate, its images veiled in dust. Now, your profound favor has been bestowed, commanding its restoration. This abbey, adjacent to the Jade Purity precinct, was once a center of Daoist learning. Later, it was renamed Zhenyuan Abbey, then designated the Purple Ultimate Palace. In the Zhide era, it was renamed Xingsheng, fronting the broad thoroughfare and bordered by the Jin River to the east. Truly a numinous site, a blessed place within the imperial capital. Its gates and halls remain intact, its sacred images preserved. It is a trace of immortals through the ages, a land of fortune for the imperial city. Now, it undergoes thorough renovation, all impurities swept away. Dust is cleared from its humble corners, revealing jade-like visages; tiles and bricks are purged from the overgrown thickets, and a jasper altar is newly raised. Rain and dew nourish the trees, enhancing their splendor; incense and musk adorn the countenances, imbuing them with solemn dignity. Zhang Qian and his peers devote themselves to carving and polishing, faithfully upholding their duties. Evening chimes and morning bells pray for Your Majesty’s longevity; morning incense and evening candles seek the eternal flourishing of the imperial enterprise. I, though unworthy, have been counted among the faithful and personally honored by your radiant favor. My gratitude is boundless.

**Memorial of Thanks for the Imperial Favor of Bestowing a Bell for the Yamen Hall**

Your servant has received the imperial decree bestowing a bell to be struck during rituals in the Riyuan precinct before the Yamen Hall. This grace descends from the heavens, honoring the faithful, filling me with joy beyond measure, and amplifying the radiance of my humble station. I reflect that Your Majesty’s virtue spans the Two Modes and shelters the Three Luminaries.

We lay bare our hearts to the ten directions, surrendering our lives to the myriad heavens. With lamps kindled and incense burning, we convey our sincerity and earnestness.

We humbly pray that the Three Honored Ones may pause their radiant presence to gaze upon our crimson hearts, and that the ten thousand sages may turn their chariots to bestow their mysterious blessings. Above, may they uphold the altars of state, harmonizing with heaven and earth to ensure peace and prosperity; below, may they assist the sagely person, shining with the brilliance of sun and moon. May the auspicious stars of the Three Terraces forever illuminate the earth’s foundations. May the strategies of the ancestral temple and the plans of the court forever govern the wells and towns. May one region flourish in peace, the four borders remain secure, pestilence be kept at bay, and weapons of war stay sheathed.

May we, your servants, along with our nine generations of ancestors and seven generations of kin, transcend the gates of the underworld; may our five clans and six relations be truly blessed with prosperity. May sins and transgressions be dissolved, and calamities and misfortunes be pacified. May agriculture and sericulture be preserved in abundance, and the suffering and afflicted all find relief. May dragon deities guard and stabilize, and wind and rain be harmoniously regulated. May the transformative power of the Dao spread far and wide, and its numinous might extend universally.

Across the vast nine lands and the teeming four kinds of beings, by the merit of the Yellow Altar’s universal repentance and the command of the Most High’s Nine Dragons, may all ascend to the fruits of the Dao and universally mount the immortal ranks. May the wandering souls of flower-strewn sacrifices and the spirits touched by frost and dew no longer suffer from disease and pestilence, each attaining rebirth. Wherever the power of the Dao reaches, may eternal fortune prevail.

---

The Liu Yin, Fei Shun, and Huanglu Memorial for the Yellow Register Rites:

We regard the pure and tranquil origin as the foundation of the profound mystery, establishing teachings; the root of creation relies upon the wondrous pivot to manifest its works. Households and states receive it and flourish, while past and present revolve by it without exhaustion. Of all transformations, the Dao’s influence first emerged before the emperors. Now, as the sagely and wise govern the heavens, the primary terraces divide their domains, spreading and magnifying virtue and the Dao, nurturing and fostering the multitudes. Their benevolence rivals that of Yao, Shun, and Yu, and their virtue surpasses that of Hou Ji and Gao Yao. The myriad regions enjoy peace, and the four borders know no peril. Moved by this extraordinary grace, how can we ascend to repay it?

Thus, we lead and encourage our subordinates to examine and adhere to the scriptural canons, meticulously adorning the altar grounds and fully observing the rites of purification. With refined incense and lamps, we convey our earnestness, and with offerings of faith, we express our sincerity. We focus our thoughts on the Nine Pures and direct our hearts toward the Three Realms.

We humbly pray that the mysterious light may descend to illuminate, and that the Most Sages may spiritually commune, graciously perceiving the sentiments of all and abundantly bestowing their vast blessings. Above, may they uphold the imperial enterprise, gloriously assisting the sagely court, shining as brightly as the three luminaries and standing as firmly as heaven and earth. In the lands of Kun Pond and Phoenix Cave, may the sound of teachings spread afar; in the regions of Mulberry Ford and Meng Valley, may the scripts and decrees be unified.

May the frontier regions be safeguarded, and the generals be aided and protected. May the heavenly blessings forever increase, and the span of life grow ever broader. May our nine generations of ancestors in the dark realms transcend suffering and pass through the gates of obscurity; may our five clans and all relations enjoy the good karma of the Dao’s domain. Within the borders, may the three agricultural seasons yield abundant harvests stored in granaries; amid the governance, may auspicious omens daily be recorded in the annals.

May weapons of war fall silent, and pestilence be kept at bay. For those with lingering bones and wandering souls, long grieving in wind and dew, or suffering in ruined tombs and dilapidated temples, may they, by this meritorious cause, all attain wondrous joy. May dragon deities remain peacefully in their abodes, and the people and officials flourish anew. May all living beings, great and small, together ascend to the realm of blessings.

---

Memorial for the Yellow Register Rites on the Occasion of the Imperial Heir’s Birth:

We have heard that the Dao is supreme, employing its mysterious power to give birth to and nurture heaven and earth; the emperor is most honored, wielding the great pivot to govern and shape creation. He broadly oversees the myriad states and distantly rules the multitudes, receiving the radiant mandate from the Three Pures and establishing the grand foundation across the nine lands. Thus, jade charts accumulate auspicious signs, and the Silver River shines with splendor, giving birth to the illustrious heir and expanding the great enterprise.

Now, as auspicious rainbows shimmer with color and precious lightning flashes with light, during this season when the sun’s brilliance awakens and the entire land reverently observes this sacred time, we dare to open the cloud-bound scriptures and humbly approach the immortal altars. We prepare the sacred precincts of the Numinous Treasure and solemnly convene the grand assembly of longevity. Whale-bone chimes and phoenix bells resound through the nine heavens; crane flames and dragon smoke convey our sincerity to the Three Realms.

We humbly pray that the imperial domain may flourish eternally, equaling the boundless rain and dew; that the sagely lifespan may rise high, matching the vastness of the eight seas. May the six palaces and inner offices harmoniously assist the imperial residence, and the myriad beings and regions widely proclaim the wise virtue. May the imperial heir possess the dragon’s pattern and phoenix’s form, as steadfast as mountains and as pure as pines, surpassing the Han and exceeding the Zhou, wisely supporting the unified realm and universally harmonizing transformation, extending even to the humble and black-haired people.

May all together revere the era of the Dao and unite in the governance of non-action. Your servant, so-and-so, cannot express the utmost of his reverent prayers and devout surrender.

---

Memorial for the Yellow Register Rites Offered by Wang Chengxiu, Grand Master for Splendid Happiness, on Behalf of His Mother:

We have heard that the supreme sages transmitted their canons, and the heavenly perfected established teachings. Their divine works save all beings, leaving nothing—neither the moving nor the still—unattended; their benevolent power spreads grace, universally reaching both the ascending and the descending. From the most ancient times to this very day, we have received their blessings and kindness, the limits of which are beyond knowing.

Thus, in the northern precincts of Mount Feng, they secretly dispelled the dust of evil and pestilence; in the southern precincts of the Dipper’s extremity, they broadly bestowed the warmth of creation and sustenance. Yet only through reverence and purity can one attain spiritual resonance. Your servant, though base and insignificant, has been honored by the shade of the Dao, encountered the wise favor, and ascended through the ranks of office. Within, I attend the celestial steps, ascending high above the nine heavens; without, I hold the bamboo tally, honored to govern a thousand miles.

At times, I must solemnly lead troops, wielding the authority of punishment and law; at others, I must pacify the frontier regions, employing the majesty of command. Fearing that I may deviate from the mean or incur blame, I am ever vigilant and anxious, my heart truly burdened.

Now, my mother, Lady Dou, born under the celestial signs of *jiazi* in such-and-such a month, has been ensnared by baleful influences and afflicted with illness. Though she has diligently taken remedies, she has yet to recover. I fear this may stem from karmic debts or lingering grievances from past lives, where sins of former existences and this present one have entwined. Perhaps it is the malign aspect of stars or the inauspicious passage of years that has brought misfortune, wearing down her fate and fortune. Day and night, I am consumed by anxiety, at a loss for how to aid her. Moreover, as I am charged with royal duties, journeying far upon the roads, I cannot personally attend her at home, nor prepare her medicines and meals. My heart races across ten thousand valleys; my gaze stretches beyond a thousand mountains. I can only rely on the compassion of the Great Dao, hoping for the efficacy of spiritual resonance.

Thus, I turn in devotion to the sacred observance, bowing my head before the flower-strewn altar. I establish a *Huanglu* Daoist ritual, invoking the Perfected and Supreme Saints of the Mysterious Realms. May the sagely gaze turn toward me, bestowing blessings and good fortune. Grant my mother an exchange of her brief span for a long and prosperous life. Dissolve her calamities, wash away her misfortunes, harmonize the six *qi*, and restore health to her hundred meridians. May her faults be absolved, her grievances settled, and her karmic debts resolved. Let her behold the radiance of sun and moon, and receive anew the blessings of creation and sustenance. May those lost in the three wretched paths and the six realms of existence alike partake of this meritorious cause, together attaining the grace of goodness. May the Nine Mysteries open the way to salvation, and the Five Lineages dwell in peace.

If I may ever serve my parents in life, I shall fulfill my filial duty with sweetness and devotion. Honoring the sagely court, I shall forever offer my loyal and sincere heart. With this solemn vow, I humbly submit to the mysterious protection. Unable to contain my earnest supplication and reverent plea, I respectfully submit this petition.

---

**Petition for the Huanglu Ritual by Attendant Censor Hu**

I have heard that the wondrous origin is subtle and imperceptible, the utmost truth empty and tranquil. Through the workings of divine power, it nurtures and transforms; through the molding of all things, it brings forth creation. Its responses are impartial, its circulation tireless. Thus, across the Nine Mysteries and the Three Antiquities, all proclaim its encompassing compassion; between heaven and earth, all bathe in its nurturing grace. The golden precepts and jade statutes, the cloud-script and jade chapters, precede the myriad dharmas in bestowing their teachings, and through the nine schools, they save the world. Great indeed is this supreme teaching—beyond all praise.

I have long been favored by the grace of the Dao, and now rejoice in this glorious era. I wander in the mysterious workings of creation, bathing in the imperial wind. At ease, I follow the harmony of heaven; in all things, I partake of the great transformation. Early on, I entered the secret registers, ever striving to cultivate clarity and sincerity. Like fire-drill and incense, I have maintained reverence from dawn to dusk; like jade rituals and treasured texts, I dare not falter in respect and devotion. My kin and close relations have ever enjoyed its sheltering protection.

Thus, I now perform the *Huanglu* ritual with utmost sincerity, offering it to the mysterious favor. Following the rites of the Ten Flowers and Three Realms, I prepare the feathered fans, chime-stones, frost-bells, and ritual platforms. My heart turns to the myriad saints; my head bows to the hosts of heaven. I humbly beseech that you look upon my sincere devotion and, in your boundless grace, bestow blessings and good fortune.

Grant that my nine ancestors and seven generations ascend to heaven and attain the Dao; that my six relations and five lineages receive fortune and glory. May the living and the dead alike know the benevolence of salvation; may all, in motion and stillness, receive the gift of peace and constancy. May disasters and misfortunes cease, grievances be settled, and faults be absolved; may lifespans be extended, and all beings under heaven—all that lives upon the earth—share in the bond of virtue. May they forever delight in the harmonious transformation of the Dao. Unable to contain my reverent plea, I respectfully submit this petition.

---

**Petition for the Ritual for the Deceased Daughter by Li Xuanjing**

I, from my humble origins, early embraced the true teaching. I have been deeply favored by the mysterious grace, long blessed by the divine favor. Yet, entangled in worldly affairs and bound by the web of the age, I have long been constrained by official duties, unable to fulfill my original aspirations. Though I yearn for the feathered robe and long to take flight, my desire remains unfulfilled. In my devotion to cultivation and reverence, I dare not neglect my private sincerity. Yet, misfortune has befallen me: my daughter has passed away. Time slips away, and my grief is unbearable.

My daughter, in her fifteenth year, was wed to the Yi family. After her husband’s death, she vowed to dedicate herself to the Dao. She had already made her ritual robes and copied scriptures and registers, intending to wear the cap and sash and devote herself to cultivation. But when I was called away on royal business, her wish could not be fulfilled. Soon after, she fell ill and suddenly passed away. Holding my hidden sorrow, I have no way to express it; thinking of the gates of the underworld, my resentment only grows.

I humbly beseech the Three Honored Ones to show compassion, and the host of saints to take pity. May you, in your boundless mercy, bestow the grace of deliverance. Let her soul find refuge and return to the fold. May the karmic debts of her past lives be dissolved, and the faults of this existence be absolved. Rescue her from the suffering of the dark springs, and let her dwell in the bliss of the good realms. May the mysterious power of the Dao ever protect and guide her.

The scriptures, registers, and ritual robes she had prepared, I now reverently burn before the ritual altar, offering them in supplication. I humbly beseech the Perfected Saints to look upon my foolish heart and command her soul to receive and ascend. Unable to contain my earnest plea, my grief, and my sorrow, I respectfully submit this petition.

**Petition for the Birthday Offering of the Eastern Court by Heavenly Commissioner He Wenji**

I have heard that when Heaven and Earth divided their numinous essence and sovereign and subject established their positions, they necessarily relied upon assistance and support to bring about the flourishing of all things. As the wind awaits the tiger and the cloud responds to the dragon, so too do omens appear in dreams and auspices manifest in cauldrons. The wise are born in accordance with their images, as Gao Yao and Kui emerged in the time of the Tai clan; the virtuous rise in succession, as the Eight Elements of Yao’s reign and the noble winds of the Yu court. None failed to illuminate the imperial enterprise and shine forth in the annals of history, bringing peace to the multitudes and blessing the realm entire.

Now, as the year bears the cyclical sign *renchen*, the day holds *gengwu*, the new moon aligns with the celestial markers, and the month accords with the Water Balance. Auspicious omens gather at the Southern Dipper, and propitious radiance converges upon the Eastern Mound. The balmy breeze enters the pitch-pipes, the stellar fire heralds good fortune, the birth-star descends upon Mount Song, and the season is truly fitting. Though I, unworthy, hold a place among the blue-robed officials, I dare to beseech the grace of the Mystic Saints. With reverence, I approach the resplendent altar, praying for the bestowal of boundless fortune. Orchid lamps burn through the night, sandalwood incense rises at dawn. Looking upward, I present the threefold petition, that it may surely reach the scrutiny of the Nine Heavens.

I humbly hope that with azure tablets and vermilion brushes, my name may be inscribed in the Eastern Pole’s register of longevity; that with crimson slips and vermilion records, I may be enrolled in the Southern Palace’s ledger of attainment. May my years rival the mountains in height, my emoluments match the seas in depth. May my joyous realm grow ever clearer, and the virtue of the mulberry-clad one be manifest. May the wild geese in formation inherit the splendor of the Three Terraces, and the carp in the courtyard surpass the seven generations of heroes. May I refine and govern the Nine Regions, aiding the Primordial Sage, unifying governance, and harmonizing customs in great unity. May the blessings extend universally to all lands, and the culture of concord be eternally secured.

I, so-and-so, having received extraordinary favor, reflect upon my own emptiness and frailty. Only by knocking my head before the numinous and true do I express my profound gratitude. Unable to contain my earnest and reverent devotion, I respectfully submit this petition.

**Petition for the *Mingzhen* Offering for the Deceased Son Zhaoyin by Military Commissioner of Xuan Sheng Army, Wang Dang**

I have heard that the great transformation knows no bounds, and the divine power is universally bestowed. It penetrates the realms of darkness and light, responding to all appeals, and extends its grace to both the living and the dead. None are left unrelieved, and from ancient times to the present, all have received its blessings.

Recently, I led an expedition to the northern lands, commanding troops in battle. With black bows drawn against the foe, I swore to fulfill my loyal duty; wielding carved halberds, I pledged my life to cleanse the nation’s store. Yet the mountains and rivers were vast, the supply lines strained by transport. As I strove to bring matters to order, my anxiety and vigilance were acute. Moreover, the soldiers suffered from pestilence, their dead and wounded strewn along the roads. My youngest son, Zhaoyin, was also afflicted by illness, his life hanging by a thread. With sincere devotion, I made vows and supplications, hoping for the scrutiny of the Mystic Saints. Soon after, we turned our weapons homeward, sparing the court from neglect. Upon returning to the vermilion steps, I reverently received the emperor’s grace and humbly acknowledge the favor of the Dao. Thus, I now offer thanks and repay this debt.

Following the standards of the *Dongxuan* and the rituals of the *Lingbao*, I have examined the rites for the long night of the Nine Dark Springs and adhered to the *Yugui*’s *Mingzhen* protocols. With utmost sincerity, I have conducted this fast and offering to repay the divine mercy.

I humbly beseech the Three Realms to shine their light and the hosts of heaven to show compassion. May the nine generations of ancestors and the seven lineages be delivered from the suffering of the dark gates, and may my kin and relations enjoy felicity in this illustrious age.

I bear the karmic faults of past lives and the enmities of former existences. Since assuming my duties, I have incurred both public and private transgressions—whether in rewards or punishments misapplied, or judgments ill-considered. The resentment of the people and my own errors are recorded in the unseen ledgers. Thus, obstacles have constantly beset me, and I have known no smooth passage. Day and night, my heart is heavy with sorrow and trepidation. Through this offering and repentance, I beg for the absolution of all these faults.

My son Zhaoyin died before reaching his prime. His wandering soul now dwells in a foreign realm; his untimely passing fills me with profound grief. Whether by malevolent influences or the restraint of dark spirits, I earnestly implore the power of the Dao to guide his spirit to life. May he cross the Southern Palace’s flowing fire and ascend to the radiant precincts of the Upper Realms. May he partake in the mysteries, attain enlightenment, and ascend to perfection. May his sins be absolved and his karmic debts resolved.

May my own calamities be lifted, my misfortunes dispelled, and my rank, emoluments, and longevity further extended. With unwavering devotion, I shall forever repay the emperor’s grace; through diligent cultivation, I shall uphold the protection of the Perfected Ones.

---

**Petition for the *Mingzhen* Offering for the Deceased Father by Wang Chengyan**

I have heard that the Supreme Dao unfolded its plan, and the Three Honored Ones bestowed their teachings. Their kindness extended to both the hidden and the manifest, their grace permeated life and death. They traversed the Eight Gates, spreading compassion to relieve suffering; moved by the sorrows of the dark night, they turned the torch of the Dharma to cast its light. The Southern Palace opens its courtyard of refinement, and the cinnabar registers initiate the ledgers of transcendence. The wise youths of the upper realms desire to know the causes of sin and blessing; the flying deities and divine beings request the forms of repentance and supplication. Expounding the profound and wondrous canon of *Mingzhen*, they deliver souls from the dark gates; unfolding the numinous rites of the *Yugui*, they dissolve the trials of the deceased. The obscurities of the mysterious and pure are dispelled, and parched sorrows are quenched. All lost souls are rescued and become beings of bliss. Through endless kalpas, all bathe in the mysterious mercy.

My late father encountered the winds of the Dao in his time and frequently partook in the sacred registers. Born in an age of sagely rule, he repeatedly attained official honors. Yet within the web of the world, could he have been without error? Amid the dust of the mortal realm, he must have incurred transgressions. Moreover, as steward of the kitchens, he was required to slaughter; as commander of troops, he often meted out punishments. Leading an army in the field or serving in the inner court, he may have oppressed the strong or protected the weak. Though he issued three commands and five exhortations, any misjudgment of severity or leniency would have constituted an offense. Separated from his homeland by war and chaos, his ancestral tombs may have been desecrated, and disputes over graves may have extended to his descendants. In selling his property and relocating his residence, the construction of earth and timber may have offended the bright spirits. For all these causes of anxiety, I now seek repentance and absolution.

Thus, I have followed the standards of the *Lingbao* and established a *Mingzhen* ritual altar. With pure incense and lamps, abundant offerings and sincere vows, I lay bare my heart and beg for grace. I humbly implore the Three Honored Ones of the Supreme and the hosts of saints in the ten directions to cast their divine light downward and pour forth their benevolent favor. May my late father’s accumulated sins and deep calamities across lifetimes be pardoned, his name erased from the earthly ledgers, and his essence cleansed in the celestial thoroughfares.

For past transgressions of accidental harm, for the debts of former grievances, for the faults that have extended to descendants, and for the blemishes of ancestral resentments—may all these be absolved, leaving inner and outer purity.

Thus, I beseech that the elixir of divine refinement be bestowed, that his name be inscribed in the Registers of Azure Radiance. May he bypass the trials of Mount Tai and Fengdu, and swiftly attain the celestial path of blessed halls. Above, may the Nine Lineages be delivered, the Seven Ancestors ascend; may graves rest in peace, the netherworld lie still. May the Three Paths and Six Realms together partake in this sublime merit, and may both kin and allies alike receive luminous protection.

With heart carved open and tears wiped in blood, I bow my head and pray to Heaven. Overcome with sobbing and choking grief, I humbly submit these words.

---

**Prayer for Clear Skies by the Crown Prince at a Banquet for Generals**

It is said that the supreme Dao responds to circumstances as echo answers sound, and that the enlightened spirits attend to devotion as shadow follows form. Reflecting on the unseen blessings I have received, I am ever grateful for the grace bestowed.

On the twenty-second day of the sixth month, the Crown Prince hosted a gathering for his generals, having already selected an auspicious hour. As this was the season of summer rains, prayers for clear skies were offered. Indeed, the divine favor was granted, and this earnest plea was answered. In but a moment, the torrential downpour ceased. The mountains gleamed in dawn’s verdant light, the sky cleared as if a screen had drawn back the clouds; the six directions were swept by pure winds, and the sun, hastening onward, saw the Radiant One take up the reins. The banquet was fully prepared, and all within and without rejoiced together.

Now, as we prepare to mobilize our forces and commence punitive action, a thousand troops surge like thunder, and the mountains and rivers are freed from the threat of mud and flood. Ten thousand horses race like stars, their armor and weapons gleaming with crystalline brilliance. Awaiting the pacification of the rebellious and the great deliverance of the people, I seek to repay the Perfected Officials and thus present this offering of a fast. Lotus lamps cluster in the night, orchid tassels flutter at dawn. The rites are performed with utmost reverence, incense and flowers abundant in their splendor.

May this reach the sages of the Pure Capital, and may the merits of the Purple Palace be further exalted. I knock my head in reverence to the mysterious power, that the great enterprise may flourish. Overcome with devotion, I humbly submit these words.

**The Emperor’s Prayer for the Yellow Register Fast in Honor of Lord Lao**

It is said that before the chaos of primordial vastness, beyond the formless and silent, there dwells the Supreme Sage, whose radiance fills the Nine Heavens. He expounds the school of tranquil emptiness and practices the teaching of non-action. From the Three Antiquities onward, across the ten thousand regions, the reverence for the true wind has assisted and fulfilled the transformations of the age.

Since the inception of governance and the assumption of the throne, I have constantly striven to manifest sincerity, ever offering reverence and devotion. The divine favor has been repeatedly bestowed, and auspicious blessings have followed one another. The immortal abode granted the talisman of the Mandate, greatly securing the foundation of the realm; the Hall of Audience gave rise to prayers of supplication, and the response was invariably felt.

Thus, wind and rain have been harmonious, malevolent influences have not arisen, the four borders have known no alarms, and the hundred grains have flourished. Grateful for these graces, I earnestly seek to express my thanks.

Therefore, at this season, I specially establish the fast altar, observing three days of reverent solemnity and six periods of purification. I hope that through this offering, I may repay the mysterious power above.

Now, as I dispatch masters and disciples to quell the rebellious, I still rely on the power of the Dao to eradicate the nests of evil. Borrowing the might of Fenglong and Lieque, may the clans of the greedy and rapacious be swept away. May further blessings be bestowed, and the realm forever enjoy peace. Overcome with devotion and longing, I humbly submit these words.

**Prayer by the Imperial Son-in-Law of Shuzhou for the Yellow Register Ritual of Disaster Dispelling and Salvation**

Your servant has heard that the supreme Dao is profound and subtle, its mysterious power vast and great. It encompasses the myriad heavens to spread transformation and extends its grace to all beings.

Thus it can descend to deliver those beyond the gates of darkness, broadly pacify the state and nation, stabilize and secure the land, and harmonize and enlighten the spirits. All rejoice in the governance of the Ruler, exhausting the power of compassionate mercy. From ancient times to the present, none—whether hidden or manifest—are left unblessed.

Your servant has long revered the mysterious grace and early received the imperial favor. Yet before I could render even the slightest service, I was suddenly honored with the dignity of office, burdened with the weight of manifold duties, and charged with overseeing criminal law, adjudicating disputes. I feared straying from the principles of benevolence and forgiveness; leading troops, I truly lacked the essentials of discipline and order, and my actions often incurred faults and blame. Constantly gripped by trepidation and anxiety, since assuming governance of this commandery, I have ever remained vigilant and cautious. Yet calamity and punishment have swiftly befallen me—how dare I hope for survival? Bound by ritual constraints, there is no escape from destruction. Though I cling to this fleeting breath, further profound grace has descended. With bloodied tears, I cry out to Heaven—lonely and helpless, to whom can I appeal?

I have heard that the Mysterious Origin established the teachings, and the Purple Yang possesses the rites of deliverance; the Orthodox Unity transmitted its precepts, and the Yellow Register offers the path of repentance and prayer. Therefore, I dare to solemnly purify the public office, erect the altar for the fast, prostrate myself before the Nine Heavens with this memorial, and send forth my words to the Three Realms. I humbly implore the Three Honored Ones and the host of sages to extend their compassionate mercy; may the nightly courts and the gates of the Yellow Springs open the way to ascension. May the soul of the Lady of Yun State, such-and-such, attain peace and prosperity, her blessings and goodness perfumed by virtue. May all her accumulated transgressions and deep stains be washed away. Unbound by the earthly prisons, may she ascend directly to the Heavenly Hall.

May the seven generations of ancestors and the nine lineages of descendants, all those departed and passed away, together ascend by the power of the Dao and assemble in the courtyard of blessings. Within the halls of this dwelling, repeatedly renovated and altered, I fear that disturbances may have arisen, preventing tranquility. I pray that through the merit of this fast and offering, the transgressions of offense and violation may be resolved. May the dragon spirits return to their positions, the earth gods be at peace, the residence be favorable and fitting, and all misfortunes and disasters be extinguished. May the city gods of the walls and moats, the local deities of the wards and domains, and the true officials of the land secretly receive divine favor and forever dwell in the land of blessings.

Above, I wish for the imperial enterprise to be firmly prosperous and the sagely lifespan to extend in abundance. May the Crown Prince and the various princes uphold great fortune in service to the state; may the empress, consorts, and imperial concubines receive radiant blessings to assist the court. May the officials within and beyond the court, the six armies, and the myriad people together rejoice in flourishing fortune and attain perfect peace and stability. May the years bring abundant harvests, and the customs be free from plague and pestilence. Within the realm, may the ten thousand regions be unified. May all together reach the land of benevolence and longevity, and together uphold the transformation of supreme peace.

With utmost reverence, I prostrate myself, lay bare my heart, and offer my sincerest and most earnest prayers.

Respectfully submitted by Zhang Taibo, Prefect of Qiongzhou, on behalf of the restoration of the withered cypress at Heming, for the performance of the Golden Register Fast.

I have heard that the supreme Dao is profoundly penetrating, and divine power broadly operates. It shapes and completes Heaven and Earth, and assists and praises the emperors and kings.

The sovereigns of Fuxi, Shennong, and Suiren, the lords of Yao, Shun, Yu, and Tang—none failed to take the profound and formless as their teacher, drawing forth harmony and radiance. Thus did they secure the enduring majesty of their dynasties and amplify the resplendence of their renown. Some rode the winds across the azure seas; others attained ranks in the Purple Courts. Their light illumined the nine distant realms, their longevity matched the Three Luminaries.

We humbly reflect upon the Great Emperor of Shu, who governs the pivot of the cosmos and grasps the Dipper to stabilize the primordial. Wielding the Great Image, he pacifies Hua and Yi; mounting the Six Dragons, he soothes the hundred millions. His virtue surpasses that of Yao and Yu; his sagacity exceeds that of Fuxi and Shennong. The lords of the felt tents and distant lands present tribute and turn toward civilization; the barbarians beyond the Han’s farthest reaches, though their tongues differ, come as guests. His beneficence saturates mountains and rivers; his benevolence extends to grasses and trees. Sacred birds nest in the inner gardens; auspicious beasts dwell in Shanglin. The triple blossoms manifest omens; the ten cowries signal wonders. Yet still he labors in humility, yielding virtue to the celestial mandate; though his deeds overflow the bamboo annals, his modesty deepens.

Now, with the hidden aid of immortals and the gracious descent of numinous transformation, profound blessings moisten the withered roots, and branches and trunks revive upon the dead cypress. When the wind stirs the verdant cliffs, its fragrance drifts far and near; when the moon passes the sacred altar, the luxuriant shadows reappear. This auspicious sign surpasses all in antiquity. It reveals the flourishing of the imperial lineage and the eternal endurance of the sacred reign. Though the sprouting grain in the ancestral temple and the *ming* leaves in the vermilion court were wondrous of old, they pale beside this divine response.

I, honored to encounter this flourishing fortune and entrusted with the seal of this prefecture, have witnessed this supreme omen. With brush and ink, I present it at the Dragon Gate; with silk and thread, it is proclaimed upon the Phoenix Edict. Within the secluded hall, the divine forms have been rendered: robes of kingfisher clouds and cinnabar brocade; vessels of dark jade and yellow cong; treasures of stellar radiance and solar essence; the distinctions of the Five Florals and Seven Honors; chariots drawn by two steeds or six horses; palanquins of cloud-wings and rosy canopies. Here are the deputy ministers and the eight mountain stewards who assist the Mandate; the august presences of the Marchmount Lords and Water Sovereigns; the ranks of the Stream Maidens and River Marquises; the elders of mountains and forests, the numinous overseers of pools and islets; the courts of emperors and kings, the offices conferred by canonical decree. Some govern the sea’s edge, eastward reaching Fangzhu; others preside over grotto-heavens, westward neighboring Kunlun’s peaks.

May all shake forth thunder and lightning, roar with dragons and whales. They inspect the hidden and manifest, record the rivers and marshes. They uphold the Supreme’s orthodox and true principles, proclaim the emperors’ nurturing grace. Drinking of the six qi, they complete the great transformation. Like autumn, winter, spring, and summer, they follow the seasonal commands without fail; like wind, rain, snow, and frost, they balance the year’s work without error. All receive the Mandate of Xuanyuan, each wielding the authority of governance. With the Marchmounts and waterways’ numinous hosts, they fulfill the offices of celestial oversight.

Thus the Perfected Lord of Mystery and Silence, bearing the weight of the august sanctuary, assumes the solemnity of imperial presence. The order of audience and tribute must be arrayed in solemn ranks. Now the master’s brush and artisan’s hand have adorned the walls in sequence, gleaming as stars in formation, towering like clouds in embrace. Thereupon, flowing robes and trailing sleeves, jade swords and pearl-studded scabbards; fiery pendants holding stars, jade tablets gathering moonlight. Some with faces like jasper and sleeves of fresh bloom seem to descend from Guye’s peaks; others in strange forms and wondrous postures appear to mirror the shores of Xunyang. The pigments are fully arrayed, resplendent and lifelike.

This must surely resonate with the divine spirits, entwining blessings and felicity. Above, it upholds the state; beside, it protects the common folk. It harmonizes the ten rains and five winds to bring forth the harvest; it pervades the nine provinces and six directions to achieve great harmony. Its vast design rivals the sun and moon, heaven and earth; its mysterious transformation encompasses all creatures, from the crawling to the rooted. Reverently we perform the libation and offering, earnestly we voice our prayers. We await the descent of mighty numen, the sure bestowal of auspicious favor.

Respectfully submitted.
